Award.AwardTitle: Reinforcement learning in the human brain: Dimensions, features, and contexts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Human decision-making depends not only upon logical reasoning about the world, but also trial-and-error learning to associate features and actions with rewarding and punishing outcomes. These reinforcement-learning mechanisms have well-known neural correlates, and theories of such learning provide excellent accounts for human behavior in limited contexts. However, trial-and-error learning has typically been studied in laboratory tasks in which value-associated features are known and are the only stimulus aspects presented to subjects. Thus, theories of how this type of learning is accomplished in the real world face a key problem: there are a multitude of potentially relevant aspects of experience that co-occur with any given decision or outcome, so which associations should be learned and guide future behavior? This project explores how humans cope with a multidimensional world when making experience-guided decisions. A better understanding of human decision-making behavior will facilitate more complete theories of learning, enable us to better predict and enhance real-world decision-making, and improve understanding of how such decision-making might break down due to mental disorders. This project will provide research opportunities for undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral students, and include broad public outreach in the form of online demonstrations and explanations of models of learning and decision-making. Further, the proposed activity includes a yearly workshop on MRI methods, which will provide training opportunities in new methods and outreach to students and faculty across fields.

The proposed project will use computational modeling of behavior and model-based fMRI to assess how humans learn about relevant and irrelevant features of the world during reward-guided decision-making. The first study will address whether irrelevant stimulus dimensions are tracked with respect to value, both in terms of choice behavior and in terms of neural representations of value. Specifically, the project will ask whether reward prediction error signals in ventral striatum and elsewhere in the brain are explained solely by relevant feature-value associations, or whether irrelevant feature-value associations are also tracked neurally and influence behavior. The second study will examine whether learned statistical contingencies in one domain, visual perception, arbitrarily influence value learning both in terms of behavior and brain activity. Findings from this study will illuminate how distinct associative learning mechanisms interact to guide behavior. Finally, a third study will examine the role of context in reward-guided decision-making, examining how well contextual features can be incorporated into decision-making. The results of this work will guide development of human reinforcement learning theories towards accommodating the complexity of real-world decision-making environments. This project will illuminate the degree to which control over which particular associations guide behavior is exerted during learning or at the time of choice.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Humans learn about the world in myriad ways, including by experiencing repeated links between actions or stimuli and rewards (“reinforcement learning”), and combinations of stimuli (“statistical learning”). These are often studied in the lab in highly simplified tasks, but real-world learning takes places in a complicated environments where lots of stimuli appear and events occur, only some of which are relevant to what you intend to learn and some of which are not. The research supported by this grant examined how reinforcement and statistical learning are affected by irrelevant features of a task and contextual factors, and how reinforcement and statistical learning interact with one another. The results of our research led to a number of insights into how seemingly minor variations in task context and features strongly impact learning. For example, we found that when people try to learn about the relationship between the color of a stimulus and its reward value, they are significantly worse when the color items appear at different locations from trial-to-trial, rather than staying in the same position. Correspondingly, we have found neural evidence that the brain tracks the “value” of locations, even when value is not specifically linked to location, but is instead linked to features like shape or color. That is, their brains track the irrelevant value of locations over time, even though that information cannot help them make better decisions.

Our research also indicates that reward learning and statistical learning interact, such that reward can enhance both behavioral and neural evidence of incidental (unintentional) learning of statistical regularities (e.g., the fact that image A always precedes the appearance of image B). In other work that resulted from this grant, we found that other aspects of context dramatically affect learning. For example, category membership influences what you incidentally learn, such that we tend to learn associations much better if those associations are between similar things; a concrete example is that two faces are easier to learn to associate with one another than a face and an image of a house, as long as you are tasked with categorizing those items during learning. Other offshoot projects led to insights into how short-term memory guides attention, and how associating one’s self with an arbitrary image enhances processing and performance. In summary of our research findings, we found evidence in multiple domains, and in both behavior and brain responses, that trial-and-error and unintentional associative learning are strongly shaped by incidental factors. These constraints on learning help us better understand the mechanisms that underlie these abilities and could lead to progress in enhancing learning in real-world contexts.

In terms of broader impacts, this grant supported broad training efforts. Impacts included the intensive training of five graduate students, a postdoctoral scholar, and undergraduate researchers. They learned programming skills, experimental design, and neuroimaging design and analysis skills. Additionally, this project funded a workshop, course development, and development of a journal club. This helped introduce members of the University of Delaware scientific community to new neuroimaging capabilities that were brought to the campus with the arrival of a research-dedicated MRI machine and imaging center in 2016. We conducted outreach by presenting our results and demonstrations about neuroscience methods to middle school students and undergraduates from around the country. Finally, we developed some simple online web-browser demos of decision-making models used in psychology and neuroscience, suitable for use in undergraduate education.
